Money in the Banksy

26/10/2013

Image by

By undefined undefined

You're in the Big Apple, surveying the intimidating buildings around you, sightseeing and generally having a good time. Now, as you stroll through Central Park, you afford yourself a glance or two at the amiable stalls. There are a few selling artwork but you're not particularly impressed. I mean, you're hardly an art buff, a weekly reader of all the culture sections, certainly, but you're not ready to shell out a few bucks on works by nonentities. You're familiar with Banksy, a street artist, a political activist and a figure you read about often while skimming through articles such as those debating the value of art or whether art has any intrinsic value at all. You walk straight past a stall attempting to flog Banksy knock-offs and allow yourself a little chuckle, "Amateurs. $60 for an imitation?!" Banksy is currently holding a month-long residency in New York, where he is creating a new piece of art each day for his 'Better Out Than In' project. On his website, , you can view photos of his latest works, which are accompanied by terse descriptions and short audio guides. So far, as you'd expect, he's been busy with some interesting creations-- "The Sirens of the Lambs"- a slaughterhouse delivery truck driving around filled with animal toys, continually shrieking in disharmony. One which raised more eyebrows than others however, was a nondescript stall set up in central park, which appeared to be selling imitations of Banksy's art for around PS38 each, however the works were indeed authentic. The first sale took at least four hours and included a 50 per cent discount. A fortunate woman haggled for the sizeable deduction on a couple of small canvases for $60 and, without knowing it, walked away with a fortune. The rest of the day yielded merely two more customers. Two pieces went to a lady from New Zealand while a male Chicagoan picked up four 'for the walls.' A rough estimate for his works of this size seems to be around PS20,000 each. Perhaps decorating should be left to the men. Art is supposed to have intrinsic value. I've been in conversation with individuals who are infuriated that it is not this attribute which has most influence over the perception of such art. Banksy's experiment reminds us that often, the value of artwork is dependent on the number of individuals who like it. If you have a one-off product that many people want, its price will go up. Supply and demand. But does this make such a piece of art 'better' than others? If so, isn't this incredible unfair? There is an idea that as soon as something is labelled 'art' or it is placed in a gallery, it is looked at differently. Perhaps this is because we associate words such as 'art' with classical artists. Michelangelo, Da Vinci, Picasso. Certainly, they are the first thoughts that pop into my mind upon mention of the topic. This adds a perhaps inappropriate expectation to potential artists-to-be. Paintings by the likes of the aforementioned persons claim prices in the realms of millions. In my younger days I dreamt of becoming an artist for such reward, but my superficial aspirations failed to materialise on account of the nonexistence of any sort of desire or passion for art itself. My idea of intrinsic value stems from learning the story about Verrocchio's 'The Baptism of Christ.' Andrea Verrochio was the master of Da Vinci and taught him at a workshop in Florence. While Andrea was working on this painting, he allowed Da Vinci to paint one angel. It is said that upon glancing at Leonardo's handiwork, the master felt ashamed at how much his pupil had excelled beyond him and put down his paintbrush for good. Can we ever become taken aback in similar fashion? Leonardo was not a famous person at the time, just a student, yet his work had such a profound impression on his colleagues. If I cut off my ear and handed it over to a classmate, he'd be horrified. However, if I handed him Van Gogh's ear, he'd be on eBay quicker than you could say Buy It Now! Banksy suggests that what determines the price of art is what consumers are willing to pay, which is influenced by variables such as a famous face, high demand and hype. If the man himself stood by the stall I'm sure the pieces would've fetched tens of thousands at least. An outrageously higher price for exactly the same canvases. As a social experiment, Banksy receives top marks for originality and execution. Those fortunate individuals have also won in more ways than one, for along with the obvious financial benefits, they now possess an anecdote for the ages.
